questions.stem: Which of the following reaction is correct?
questions.explanation: The correct thermal decomposition reaction for lithium nitrate is: \(4 \mathrm{LiNO}_{3} \xrightarrow{\Delta} 2 \mathrm{Li}_{2} \mathrm{O}+4 \mathrm{NO}_{2}+\mathrm{O}_{2}\)
questions.tip_formula: Thermal decomposition of nitrates: Group 1 metals (except Li) give nitrites + O₂; Li and other metals give metal oxide + NO₂ + O₂
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem: The most stable carbocation for the following is:
questions.explanation: The +M effect of \(\mathrm{NH}_{2}\) is stabilizing the carbocation, making option C the most stable carbocation.
questions.tip_formula: Stability order: Resonance stabilized > +M groups > +I groups > primary carbocation
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem: The correct order of \(\mathrm{pK}_{\mathrm{a}}\) values for the following compounds is:
questions.explanation: Due to -M effect of \(-\mathrm{NO}_{2}\) group, it increases acidity; +M effect of \(\mathrm{N}\left(\mathrm{CH}_{3}\right)_{2}\) decreases acidity. Hyperconjugation of isopropyl decreases acidity. Therefore order of acidic strength: (c) > (a) > (d) > (b), so pKa order: b > d > a > c
questions.tip_formula: Higher acidity = lower pKa; Electron withdrawing groups increase acidity, electron donating groups decrease acidity
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem: Decreasing order towards \(\mathrm{S}_{\mathrm{N}} 1\) reaction for the following compounds is:
questions.explanation: The rate of \(\mathrm{S}_{\mathrm{N}} 1\) reaction depends upon stability of carbocation which follows the order: tertiary benzylic > secondary benzylic > tertiary > secondary. Therefore reactivity order: (b) > (d) > (c) > (a)
questions.tip_formula: SN1 reactivity ∝ Carbocation stability: 3° benzylic > 3° allylic > 2° benzylic > 3° > 1° benzylic > 2° > 1°
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem: In the above conversion of compound (X) to product (Y), the sequence of reagents to be used will be:
questions.explanation: The correct sequence is: (i) Fe, H⁺ for reduction of nitro group to amino group, (ii) Br₂(aq) for bromination, (iii) HNO₂ for diazotization, (iv) H₃PO₂ for deamination to remove the amino group and replace with hydrogen.
questions.tip_formula: Conversion sequence: Reduction → Bromination → Diazotization → Deamination
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem: Maximum number of electrons that can be accommodated in shell with \(\mathrm{n}=4\) are:
questions.explanation: For n=4 shell: 4s (2 electrons) + 4p (6 electrons) + 4d (10 electrons) + 4f (14 electrons) = 32 electrons total
questions.tip_formula: Maximum electrons in shell = 2n²; For n=4: 2×(4)² = 32 electrons
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem: Match List I with List II:
questions.explanation: Correct matching: [Ni(CO)₄] - sp³, [Cu(NH₃)₄]²⁺ - dsp², [Fe(NH₃)₆]²⁺ - sp³d², [Fe(H₂O)₆]²⁺ - sp³d²
questions.tip_formula: Hybridization: CO - sp³ (tetrahedral), NH₃ (square planar) - dsp², Weak field ligands - sp³d², Strong field ligands - d²sp³
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem: The \(\mathrm{Cl}-\mathrm{Co}-\mathrm{Cl}\) bond angle values in a fac\(\left[\mathrm{Co}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{3} \mathrm{Cl}_{3}\right]\) complex is/are:
questions.explanation: In facial isomer of octahedral complex [Co(NH₃)₃Cl₃], all three chloride ligands are adjacent to each other at 90° angles in the same plane.
questions.tip_formula: In octahedral geometry, adjacent ligands are at 90° and opposite ligands are at 180°
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem: Given below are two statements: One is labelled as Assertion A and the other is labelled as Reason R. Assertion A: can be easily reduced using \(\mathrm{Zn}-\mathrm{Hg} / \mathrm{HCl}\) to Reason R: \(\mathrm{Zn}-\mathrm{Hg} / \mathrm{HCl}\) is used to reduce carbonyl group to \(-\mathrm{CH}_{2}-\) group.

options.text: A is false but R is true
A is true but R is false
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A

questions.explanation: The acid sensitive alcohol group reacts with HCl, hence Clemmensen reduction is not suitable for above conversion. Therefore Assertion A is false but Reason R is true.
questions.tip_formula: Clemmensen reduction: Converts carbonyl to methylene using Zn-Hg/HCl, but not suitable for acid-sensitive groups
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem: Chlorides of which metal are soluble in organic solvents:
questions.explanation: \(\mathrm{BeCl}_{2}\) having covalent nature is soluble in organic solvent due to its high polarizing power and small size of Be²⁺ ion.
questions.tip_formula: BeCl₂ is covalent due to high polarizing power of Be²⁺ (Fajans' rule)
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem:
Given below are two statements: One is labelled as Assertion A and the other labelled as Reason R.
Assertion A: Antihistamines do not affect the secretion of acid in stomach.
Reason R: Antiallergic and antacid drugs work on different receptors.

options.text: A is false but R is true
Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
A is true but R is false
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A

questions.explanation: Antiallergic and antacid drugs work on different receptors. Antihistamines block H1 receptors for allergy, while antacids work on proton pumps or H2 receptors for acid secretion.
questions.tip_formula: H1 receptors - allergic reactions; H2 receptors - gastric acid secretion
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem:
The wave function (\(\Psi\)) of 2s is given by
\(\Psi_{2 s}=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2 \pi}}\left(\frac{1}{a_{0}}\right)^{1 / 2}\left(2-\frac{r}{a_{0}}\right) e^{-r / 2 a_{0}}\)
At \(r=r_{0}\), radial node is formed. Thus, \(r_{0}\) in terms of \(a_{0}\)
questions.explanation: At node \(\Psi_{2 \mathrm{~s}}=0\), therefore \(2-\frac{\mathrm{r}_{0}}{\mathrm{a}_{0}}=0\), which gives \(\mathrm{r}_{0}=2 \mathrm{a}_{0}\)
questions.tip_formula: For ns orbitals, number of radial nodes = n - l - 1; For 2s: 2 - 0 - 1 = 1 radial node
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem: \(\mathrm{KMnO}_{4}\) oxidises \(\mathrm{I}^{-}\) in acidic and neutral/faintly alkaline solution, respectively to
questions.explanation:
In acidic medium: \(2 \mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}+10 \mathrm{I}^{-}+16 \mathrm{H}^{+} \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{Mn}^{2+}+5 \mathrm{I}_{2}+8 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\)
In neutral/faintly alkaline solution: \(2 \mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}+\mathrm{I}^{-}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{MnO}_{2}+2 \mathrm{OH}^{-}+\mathrm{IO}_{3}^{-}\)
questions.tip_formula: KMnO₄ in acid: I⁻ → I₂; in neutral/alkaline: I⁻ → IO₃⁻
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem:
Bond dissociation energy of \(\mathrm{E}-\mathrm{H}\) bond of the " \(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{E}\) " hydrides of group 16 elements (given below), follows order.
(A) O
(B) S
(C) Se
(D) Te
questions.explanation: Bond dissociation energy of E-H bond in hydrides of group 16 follows the order: \(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}>\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}>\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{Se}>\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{Te}\) due to decreasing bond strength down the group.
questions.tip_formula: Bond dissociation energy order: H₂O > H₂S > H₂Se > H₂Te (anomalous due to H-bonding in H₂O)
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem: The water quality of a pond was analysed and its BOD was found to be 4. The pond has

options.text: Water has high amount of fluoride compounds

questions.explanation: Clean water has BOD value of <5 while polluted water has BOD of 15 or more. A BOD of 4 indicates very clean water.
questions.tip_formula: BOD < 5 ppm: clean water; BOD > 15 ppm: polluted water
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem: Match List I with List II:
questions.explanation: Correct matching: CHCl₃ + C₆H₅NH₂ - Distillation; C₆H₁₄ + C₅H₁₂ - Fractional distillation; C₆H₅NH₂ + H₂O - Steam distillation; Organic compound in H₂O - Differential extraction
questions.tip_formula: Separation techniques: Different boiling points - distillation; Close boiling points - fractional distillation; Steam volatile - steam distillation; Different solubility - extraction
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem: Boric acid in solid, whereas \(\mathrm{BF}_{3}\) is gas at room temperature because of

options.text: Strong ionic bond in Boric acid
Strong van der Waal's interaction in Boric acid
Strong hydrogen bond in Boric acid

questions.explanation: Boric acid has strong hydrogen bonding while \(\mathrm{BF}_{3}\) does not. Therefore boric acid is solid due to extensive hydrogen bonding network.
questions.tip_formula: H₃BO₃ forms 2D layers through hydrogen bonding; BF₃ is molecular with weak van der Waals forces
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem:
Given below are two statements:

Statement I: During Electrolytic refining, the pure metal is made to act as anode and its impure metallic form is used as cathode.

Statement II: During the Hall-Heroult electrolysis process, purified \(\mathrm{Al}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\) is mixed with \(\mathrm{Na}_{3} \mathrm{AlF}_{6}\) to lower the melting point of the mixture.

options.text: Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
Both Statement I and Statement II are correct

questions.explanation: In Electrolytic refining, the pure metal is used as cathode and impure metal is used as anode. \(\mathrm{Na}_{3} \mathrm{AlF}_{6}\) is added during electrolysis of \(\mathrm{Al}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\) to lower the melting point and increase conductivity.
questions.tip_formula: Electrolytic refining: Impure metal - anode; Pure metal - cathode; Cryolite lowers melting point of alumina
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem: Formulae for Nessler's reagent is:
questions.explanation: Nessler's reagent is \(\mathrm{K}_{2} \mathrm{HgI}_{4}\), used for detection of ammonia and ammonium ions.
questions.tip_formula: Nessler's reagent = K₂[HgI₄]; gives brown precipitate with NH₄⁺ ions
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem:
1 L, 0.02 M solution of \(\left[\mathrm{Co}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{5} \mathrm{SO}_{4}\right] \mathrm{Br}\) is mixed with 1 L, 0.02 M solution of \(\left[\mathrm{Co}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{5} \mathrm{Br}\right] \mathrm{SO}_{4}\). The resulting solution is divided into two equal parts (X) and treated with excess \(\mathrm{AgNO}_{3}\) solution and \(\mathrm{BaCl}_{2}\) solution respectively as shown below:
1 L Solution (\(\mathrm{X}\))+\(\mathrm{AgNO}_{3}\) solution (excess) \(\rightarrow \mathrm{Y}\)
1 L Solution (\(\mathrm{X}\))+\(\mathrm{BaCl}_{2}\) solution (excess) \(\rightarrow \mathrm{Z}\)
questions.explanation: Both complexes give same ions in solution due to ionization. Therefore both AgNO₃ and BaCl₂ will precipitate 0.02 moles each.
questions.tip_formula: Coordination compounds ionize to give counter ions; Both complexes give same ionic species in solution
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem:
Given below are two statements:

Statement I: The boiling point of three isomeric pentanes follows the order
n-pentane > isopentane > neopentane

Statement II: When branching increases, the molecule attains spherical shape with less surface area.

options.text: Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
Both Statement I and Statement II are correct

questions.explanation: Boiling point order: n-pentane (309 K) > isopentane (301 K) > neopentane (283 K). Branching decreases surface area and van der Waals forces, lowering boiling point.
questions.tip_formula: Boiling point ∝ Surface area; More branching = lower surface area = lower boiling point
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem:
The correct order of bond angle of the following species is:
(A) \(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\)
(B) \(\mathrm{PH}_{3}\)
(C) \(\mathrm{AsH}_{3}\)
(D) \(\mathrm{SbH}_{3}\)
questions.explanation: Bond angle order: \(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\) (107°) > \(\mathrm{PH}_{3}\) (93.5°) > \(\mathrm{AsH}_{3}\) (91.8°) > \(\mathrm{SbH}_{3}\) (91.3°). Due to decreasing bond pair-bond pair repulsion down the group.
questions.tip_formula: Bond angle decreases down the group due to decreasing bond pair repulsion and increasing p-character
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem: Which of the following is not a colligative property?
questions.explanation: Optical activity depends on the chiral nature of molecules and not on the number of solute particles, hence it is not a colligative property.
questions.tip_formula: Colligative properties depend only on number of solute particles, not on their nature
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem:
The correct order of \(\mathrm{pK}_{\mathrm{b}}\) values for the following amines is:
(A) \(\mathrm{CH}_{3} \mathrm{NH}_{2}\)
(B) \(\left(\mathrm{CH}_{3}\right)_{2} \mathrm{NH}\)
(C) \(\left(\mathrm{CH}_{3}\right)_{3} \mathrm{~N}\)
(D) \(\mathrm{C}_{6} \mathrm{H}_{5} \mathrm{NH}_{2}\)
questions.explanation: Basicity order: (CH₃)₂NH > CH₃NH₂ > (CH₃)₃N > C₆H₅NH₂; Therefore pKb order: C₆H₅NH₂ > (CH₃)₃N > CH₃NH₂ > (CH₃)₂NH
questions.tip_formula: Basicity: 2° aliphatic > 1° aliphatic > 3° aliphatic > aromatic amines
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem:
The correct order of wavelength of light absorbed for the following complex ions is:
(A) \(\left[\mathrm{Co}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{6}\right]^{3+}\)
(B) \(\left[\mathrm{Co}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{5} \mathrm{Cl}\right]^{2+}\)
(C) \(\left[\mathrm{Co}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{5} \mathrm{NO}_{2}\right]^{2+}\)
(D) \(\left[\mathrm{Co}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{5} \mathrm{NCS}\right]^{2+}\)
questions.explanation: Wavelength order follows the spectrochemical series: NO₂⁻ (strong field) > NCS⁻ > Cl⁻ > NH₃ (weak field). Stronger field ligand causes larger splitting, absorbing shorter wavelength.
questions.tip_formula: Spectrochemical series: I⁻ < Br⁻ < Cl⁻ < F⁻ < OH⁻ < H₂O < NH₃ < en < NO₂⁻ < CN⁻
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem:
The correct order of the first ionization enthalpy for the following elements is:
(A) Be
(B) B
(C) N
(D) O
questions.explanation: First ionization enthalpy order: N (1402) > Be (899) > O (1314) > B (801) kJ/mol. N has half-filled stable configuration, Be has fully filled s-orbital.
questions.tip_formula: IE order in period: Increases across period with exceptions at fully/half-filled stability
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem:
The correct order of solubility of the following in water is:
(A) \(\mathrm{LiCl}\)
(B) \(\mathrm{LiBr}\)
(C) \(\mathrm{LiI}\)
(D) \(\mathrm{LiF}\)
questions.explanation: Solubility order: LiCl > LiBr > LiI > LiF. Smaller anions have higher lattice energy, making LiF least soluble due to high lattice energy not compensated by hydration energy.
questions.tip_formula: Solubility depends on balance between lattice energy and hydration energy
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem:
The correct order of acidic strength for the following is:
(A) \(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\)
(B) \(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}\)
(C) \(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{Se}\)
(D) \(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{Te}\)
questions.explanation: Acidic strength increases down the group: \(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{Te}>\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{Se}>\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~S}>\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\) due to decreasing bond dissociation energy and increasing size of central atom.
questions.tip_formula: Acidic strength of hydrides increases down the group due to decreasing bond strength
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem:
The correct order of stability for the following carbocations is:
(A) \(\mathrm{CH}_{3}-\stackrel{+}{\mathrm{C}} \mathrm{H}_{2}\)
(B) \(\left(\mathrm{CH}_{3}\right)_{2} \stackrel{+}{\mathrm{C}} \mathrm{H}\)
(C) \(\left(\mathrm{CH}_{3}\right)_{3} \stackrel{+}{\mathrm{C}}\)
(D) \(\mathrm{C}_{6} \mathrm{H}_{5}-\stackrel{+}{\mathrm{C}} \mathrm{H}_{2}\)
questions.explanation: Stability order: Benzyl (D) > Tertiary (C) > Secondary (B) > Primary (A). Benzyl carbocation is stabilized by resonance with aromatic ring.
questions.tip_formula: Carbocation stability: 3° benzylic > 3° > 2° benzylic > 2° > 1° benzylic > 1° > methyl
questions.subject: Chemistry

questions.stem:
The correct order of dipole moment for the following molecules is:
(A) \(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\)
(B) \(\mathrm{NF}_{3}\)
(C) \(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\)
(D) \(\mathrm{OF}_{2}\)
questions.explanation: Dipole moment order: H₂O (1.85 D) > NH₃ (1.47 D) > OF₂ (0.30 D) > NF₃ (0.24 D). In NF₃ and OF₂, the bond moments oppose the lone pair moment.
questions.tip_formula: Dipole moment depends on both bond polarity and molecular geometry
questions.subject: Chemistry
